Key Arguments: The legislation is too broad and acts like a hammer when more precise tools are needed.
The Bill does not adequately address the use of bots or fake accounts for astroturfing.
There is a risk of over-censorship due to the incentive structure created by the Bill.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation are problematic as determining truth is complex.
The definitions of 'harm' are too broad and could stifle genuine discussion and criticism.
The Bill misunderstands the requirements for democracy to function by focusing only on top-down political content.
Notable Quotes: This legislation will act more like a hammer when instead carefully applied tweezers are needed.
Free speech is both a defence against this possibility and will be the first victim if such a state should arise.
The freedom to engage with a variety of different information is tantamount to the freedom to think.
